title: Vorticons = furries?
content:
I was drawing [img]http://i34.photobucket.com/albums/d134/Galaxieretter/Agenericvorticonthatisnotanyspecifi.png[/img] the other day in school, (It wasn't colored then. And ok ok the belt *is* a bit low... I know. So sue me.) when the dude next to me looks over and says "Dude are you drawing a furry?"

My immediate reaction was "NO!" I tried to explain that it was a Vorticon from Commander Keen and that they are supposed to be aliens. But he told me that it doesn't matter if Vorticons are suppose to be aliens, they are still furries. People make furries be aliens all the time in comics and stuff.

This got me to thinking. (Evidently something that I need to do more...) So when I got home I looked up what [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Furry]Wikipedia[/url] had on furries. Vorticons DO fit the criteria that they have on there.

I can't decide either way... I used to think that Vorticons were just aliens and totally not related to furries. Now I see how they could be mistaken for furries. Do you think that Vorticons are furries? I can't come to a conclusion.-----------------------
"Tough guys wear pink"
[img]http://img455.imageshack.us/img455/8978/mod21gb.jpg[/img]
"But fat people STILL buy lots"

title: Re: Vorticons = furries?
content:
The problem here is that the term furry is what used to be called an canabalistic term; a term that while origionally referring to a small selection of entities has become used so broadly and with such broad parameters that it has 'absorbed' various other, formerly unrelated classes of entity.

Thus, Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse were oce cartoon characters, now they're furries. Novels about furred aliens used to be sci-fi, now they're furry literature. Vorticons used to be aliens, now they're furries.

The term furry now pretty much covers anything that resembles an animal in any way. Thus now even 'bunny girls' [women wearing bunny ears] are furry, as are old classics like The Fox and the Hound It has even encompassed anthropomorphic lizards and fish.

As such Vorticons are Furries by association, not definition [You could say they're forced furries; would you like it if aliens landed, took over your planet, freed it, then told you you were a 'Xychar, some kind of comic book character?] However if you were to draw Vorticons with the intention that they were furries, they would be.

If you want to see real Vorticon fury, tell Laurael her tail is drooping.


A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/Kazz.gif[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: well
content:
Your art style does look rather furry-ish. Looking at the way the Vorticons appear in a close-up at the end of Episode 3, their ears are droopier, their eyes much more square-ish, and they don't really show their midsection or sag their jumpsuits. :-) The way you've drawn your character is basically an adolescent girl with an oversized head and big cat ears. That's very furry.

That said, I agree that the Vorticons fit the definition of "furry," although I'm a firm believer that art style and personality has a large part of what makes a person/idea "furry."

title: Re: well
content:
Well, I'd said it's only what you're intending -- if it's only Keen fan art featuring a vorticon I'd say it's just that then.

Cute picture anyways! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Eat your veggies!

title: Re: well
content:
We have fur, but we're not furrys. Vorticons are wolf-humans from an other planet. I know this because I am a vorticon!
Signed, Harvey Smith
A proud member of the beta testing society

title: Re: well
content:
Wait... there is another Catharsis fan here? Cool! Actually that comic only made me think more about this issue...

[quote]Quote:[hr]However if you were to draw Vorticons with the intention that they were furries, they would be.[hr][/quote]
Ah.. interesting.

[quote]Quote:[hr]The way you've drawn your character is basically an adolescent girl with an oversized head and big cat ears. That's very furry.[hr][/quote]
Yes I know, but I was referring to Vorticons in general. The one I drew doesn't really look like a Vorticon. I have been messing around lately trying to find out how to draw good Vorticons but I can't get it.

[quote]Quote:[hr]That said, I agree that the Vorticons fit the definition of "furry," although I'm a firm believer that art style and personality has a large part of what makes a person/idea "furry."[hr][/quote]
Ah thanks. That makes sense.

[quote]Quote:[hr] We have fur, but we're not furrys. Vorticons are wolf-humans from an other planet. I know this because I am a vorticon![hr][/quote]

title: Re: well
content:
What does Naj have to do with anything?

Ok LevelLord00... you found me out. You know that guy I had in the picture when I had my wisdom teeth removed? Yea not me. It's some dead guy I found in front of my house who got ran over. I keep his body in a big jar of formaldehyde and pull him out whenever I need to put a picture of "myself" online. (notice how "I" had no expression?) I guess it was obvious when I discovered the relationship between Xky and Laurael, my romantic feminine nature was showing through. Or it could of been my perfect spelling that obviously shows a superior female mind at work.

Question is... why does a famous furry artist such as myself frequent a Commander Keen forum? And shouldn't you be overjoyed that there is now another female that is a regular poster on this forum? I mean there is Rocket Jess but she posts like once a year. ;-)

If you really think that I am so evil, I will refrain from posting any more art on the PCKF. Although I won't stop making my furry art. I have to make a living somehow and holding a real job is WAY below someone as great as I.

You know you weren't the first to come up with the "Gal" nickname. That honor goes to Nycteris on another forum.

Oh, and LevelLord... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-moon.gif[/img]
